Conducting face-to-face group classes for children in language centers, educational centers, personal development support centers and other training centers and schools is allowed provided at a physical distance of at least 1.5 m and not more than 5 people in a room, wearing protective face masks, hand hygiene, regular airing every hour and disinfection. Restrictions do not apply to special education support centers.  The students may conduct face-to-face classes in municipalities with a 14-day morbidity of over 500 per 100 000 population if the following conditions are met: (a) a field organization has been set up for a COVID-19 study with rapid antigen tests once a week (on the first school day of the week) for students in the relevant classes (attending face-to-face training) and twice a week for pedagogical and non-teaching staff involved in on-site training, except those who have valid documents for vaccination, illness or testing; b) in case of disagreement of the parents / guardians / custodians to conduct a study for COVID-19, the student is not admitted to face-to-face training and is provided with the opportunity for distance learning in an electronic environment; (c) exceptionally, individual activities (individual lessons, consultations, ongoing assessment tests, examinations, etc.) may be conducted without applying the requirement of letter "a" for students if the individual activities are conducted outside the time of the present learning process of the classes.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206194450/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

Employers and appointment bodies in all administrations within the meaning of Art. 1 of the Administration Act organise the work process of the employees, as: (a) establish working hours with variable limits and the start of the working day between 7.30 and 10.00, unless this is not possible depending on the nature of the work; (b) assign remote work to at least 50% of staff, unless this is not possible depending on the nature of the work.   Employers in hospitals, complex oncology centres, dialysis centres, hospices and nursing homes organise the work process by admitting to work only employees with valid documents for vaccination, illness or testing within the meaning of this order. The employer can arrange for a COVID-19 study to be performed with rapid on-site antigen testing. A protocol shall be drawn up for the conducted examination, in which the names of the employee, the result of the test and the date of its performance shall be entered. The protocol is signed by the employer and the respondents. The results are valid up to 48 hours after sampling.  Visits to libraries, museums, galleries, cinemas, theatres, circus performances, concerts and other indoor performances, fitness centres, sports halls and clubs, swimming pools and complexes, balneotherapy (medical SPA) centres, SPA centres, wellness centres and thalassotherapy centres, gambling halls, casinos and food and entertainment establishments within the meaning of Art. 124 of the Tourism Act, including those to the places of accommodation, shopping malls, shops with a net retail area of ??over 300 square metres, bazaars and indoor exhibitions shall be suspended. Exceptions are allowed for shops offering mainly groceries, pharmacies, drugstores, opticians, pet shops, banks, postal and courier service providers, insurers, payment service providers and telecommunications operators' offices, whether they are stand-alone or located in a shopping centre type Mall. An exception is allowed for medical establishments and vaccination points located on the territory of shopping centres. These anti-epidemic measures may not be applied if: (a) 100% of the staff at the site / persons involved in the event have been vaccinated or have suffered from COVID-19 or have a test result certified by valid vaccination, disease or test documents, and b) the manager of the site / the organiser of the event has made a decision and has created the necessary organisation for admission to the site, respectively of the event only to persons who: (aa) have been vaccinated or have suffered from COVID-19, certified by valid vaccination or illness documents, or (bb) present a negative result from a polymerase chain reaction test for COVID-19 or a rapid antigen test (up to 48 hours before entry into the site / event) up to 72 hours prior to entry into the site / event, certified by a valid document or certificate presence of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2. (c) the conditions in points (aa) and (bb) do not apply to persons under the age of 18.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206194450/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

The holding of all mass events, such as music and other festivals, fairs, folklore initiatives and others of such nature, shall be suspended. Visits to libraries, museums, galleries, cinemas, theatres, circus performances, concerts and other indoor performances are suspended. Sports competitions are allowed without an audience. Visits to fitness centres, sports halls and clubs, swimming pools and complexes, balneotherapy (medical SPA) centres, SPA centres, wellness centres and thalassotherapy centres are suspended. Visits to gambling halls, casinos and food and entertainment establishments within the meaning of Art. 124 of the Tourism Act, including those to the places of accommodation. Visits to shopping malls, shops with a net retail area of ??over 300 square metres, bazaars and indoor exhibitions shall be suspended. Exceptions are allowed for shops offering mainly groceries, pharmacies, drugstores, opticians, pet shops, banks, postal and courier service providers, insurers, payment service providers and telecommunications operators' offices, whether they are stand-alone or located in a shopping centre type Mall. An exception is allowed for medical establishments and vaccination points located on the territory of shopping centres. The conducting of organised excursions and group visits to tourist sites in the country is suspended.  The above anti-epidemic measures may not be applied if: (a) 100% of the staff at the site / persons involved in the event have been vaccinated or have suffered from COVID-19 or have a test result certified by valid vaccination, disease or test documents, and b) the manager of the site / the organiser of the event has made a decision and has created the necessary organisation for admission to the site, respectively of the event only to persons who: (aa) have been vaccinated or have suffered from COVID-19, certified by valid vaccination or illness documents, or (bb) present a negative result from a polymerase chain reaction test for COVID-19 or a rapid antigen test (up to 48 hours before entry into the site / event) up to 72 hours prior to entry into the site / event, certified by a valid document or certificate presence of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2. (c) the conditions in points (aa) and (bb) do not apply to persons under the age of 18.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206194450/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

Private gatherings (baptisms, weddings, etc.) are allowed with the participation of no more than 15 people indoors and 30 people outdoors.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206194450/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

All persons must cover their mouth and nose with a mask or covering on all public transportation including while in railway, bus and metro stations, and airports etc.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206201619/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
There is currently no curfew in place.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206201619/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
There are no restrictions on interstate or intercity travel.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206201619/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Unitl 31 January, UK nationals (and their family members) travelling directly from the UK, a European Union member state, a European Economic Area country or Switzerland (even if that country is also in the red zone) are eligible to enter Bulgaria, but you must provide the following pieces of COVID-19 documentation in order to be allowed entry: a vaccination certificate (Bulgaria will accept either certificate of completion of a two dose vaccine course (Pfizer-BioNTech, AstraZeneca, Novavax, Moderna, Covishield, Sinopharm, Sinovac, Sputnik) or a certificate of receipt of a one dose vaccine (Janssen, Johnson & Johnson). In both cases immunization must have been completed 14 days prior to arrival; or evidence of past COVID-19 infection (a test result certificate, in English, showing a positive test result from either a PCR or rapid antigen test dated at least 11 days, but no more than 180 days, before arrival in Bulgaria). You must also provide: a negative PCR test taken within 72 hours before entry - this should include name, date of birth, details of the medical institution and date and time of the sample, and should be in English.  Until 31 January, Bulgarian nationals and permanent and long-term residents, as well as their family members who present only one of the listed documents â a certificate of vaccination or recovery or a negative PCR test, are allowed to travel but, must self-isolate for 10 days upon arrival. This 10-day quarantine period can be shortened if they perform a PCR test no earlier than 72 hours after their arrival in Bulgaria. If the result is negative, quarantine will be lifted from the day following the registration of the result.  Until 31 January, Bulgarian nationals and permanent and long-term residents, as well as their family members who do not present any of the listed documents â a certificate of vaccination or recovery or a negative PCR test, will be allowed to enter Bulgaria. However, they will be required to complete a mandatory 10-day quarantine which cannot be ended early through testing.  Only Bulgarian nationals and permanent and long-term residents, as well as their family members, will be allowed to enter from the following countries: South Africa, Mozambique, Botswana, Lesotho, Namibia, Eswatini and Zimbabwe. They will be subject to a mandatory 10-day self-isolation and a mandatory antigen testing upon entry.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206205624/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/bulgaria/entry-requirements

As of 1st February 2022. All travellers arriving to Bulgaria from a Green, Orange or Red Zone country, regardless of their citizenship, can enter without quarantine if they present an EU Digital COVID Certificate showing that the person has been vaccinated against COVID-19, has received a negative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or antigen COVID test result conducted up to 72 hours before entering the country, or has recovered from COVID-19. Similar documents which contain the same data as the EU digital certificate, such as a U.S. Centers for Disease Control (CDC) Vaccination Record Card, are also accepted.    All travellers arriving to Bulgaria from a Dark Red Zone country, regardless of their citizenship, can enter Bulgaria by presenting an EU Digital COVID Certificate showing that the person has been vaccinated against COVID-19 or has recovered from COVID-19 or a similar document which contain the same data as the EU digital certificate together with a negative PCR test result conducted up to 72 hours before entering the country.    Persons travelling from a dark red zone country who present a valid digital EU COVID certificate for vaccination for an additional (booster) dose or equivalent or similar document do not need to present a negative PCR result from 72 hours before entry into the country.    Some exceptions apply with regards to the requirement for a valid COVID certificate or equivalent.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206194450/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206201619/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206204105/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/news/3233

PCR testing is widely available at sites across the country, including hospitals and private laboratories. Currently 100 hospitals and laboratories in Bulgaria are officially accredited by the Ministry of Health.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206201619/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Any person who has made contact within 48 hours before and up to 14 days after the onset of symptoms in a patient should be considered when determining close contacts in a confirmed case of COVID-19. If the confirmed case is asymptomatic, contact is any person who has been in contact with the case within 48 hours before up to 14 days after taking the sample that led to the laboratory confirmation. All close contacts of a confirmed case of COVID-19, at the discretion of an epidemiologist from RHI, are quarantined at home or elsewhere for accommodation and medical supervision for 7 -day period, as of the last contact with the sick person. The monitoring of the health condition of each contact person is carried out by the general practitioner or the respective regional health inspectorate.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206212409/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/az-sum/kontaktno-litse

All persons must wear a mask that covers their mouth and nose in all indoor public spaces as well as in open public spaces where there is a crowd of people and it is not possible to observe a physical distance of 1.5 m. Scarves or substitute face coverings are no longer allowed in place of a mask.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206201619/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
AstraZeneca, Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are currently available and general vaccination has begun.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206201619/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No additional measures for elderly people were found.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220206194450/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

Policy change from maximum of 50 people to 30 people.    The new Order , which is in force as of today, January 13, 2021. year, the number of persons who can stay indoors at the same time from the previous 50 was reduced to 30, while more than 100 people can stay outdoors.  All gatherings within the stated limits must take place in a space that allows a mandatory physical distance of at least 2 meters between persons (except members of the same household).  Exceptionally, the new Order allows the organization of larger gatherings indoors and outdoors, provided that the size of the space allows the implementation of hygienic and epidemiological measures, but not more than 60 people indoors or 200 people outdoors, provided that all participants together have a negative antigen test (not older than 24 hours) or a PCR test (not older than 48 hours) or a certificate of overcoming COVID-19 (not older than 4 months) or a certificate of completed vaccination (not older than 6 months after receiving the second vaccine doses, ie 9 months after receiving the third vaccine dose).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220115120320/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/novost/822/od-danas-na-snazi-nove-naredbe-kriznog-stozera-federalnog-ministarstva-zdravstva-koje-je-usvojila-vlada-fbih

CONDITIONS FOR ENTRY TO BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA         (Article 2)    A foreigner who meets conditions for entry to BiH prescribed by Law on Aliens, may enter BiH if he/she at the BiH Border Crossing Points presents any of the following:    negative PCR test or rapid antigen test on SARS-CoV-2, not older than 48 hours if he/she comes from an European country, and if he/she comes from another country, not older than 72 hours until arrival at the border crossing point ofBosnia and Herzegovina,    certificate that a person has received the second dose of vaccine for COVID-19 before more than 14 days before the arrival to a Border Crossing Point of BiH or has received one dose before 14 days and more before the arrival to a Border Crossing Point of BiH, if it is a single dose vaccine,    certificate issued by doctor showing that he/she has recovered from COVID-19 in the previous period from 14 to 180 days until the arrival to a Border Crossing Point of BiH.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220113193549/http://www.granpol.gov.ba/Content/Read/76?title=Stranci&lang=en

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in BiH? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Private and public clinics throughout BiH perform PCR and serological COVID-19 tests. Payment is due in full at the time of the test and current prices are roughly 100 convertible marks (km) for PCR and 40km for antigen.  Turnaround of results and availability of testing appointments vary based on the city yet clinics in most large cities have testing options daily and return results within 24 hours.  A list of clinics known to provide COVID-19 testing in BiH can be found on our website here  Public Health Centers (Dom Zdravlja) test symptomatic individuals regardless of nationality, free of charge. To arrange a test, contact your cantonâs health center for additional guidance.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220114112145/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Transportation Options:  Are commercial flights operating? Yes  Is public transportation operating? Yes  Masks are required on public transit.  Flight schedules are reduced from normal, and subject to change.

7/2/22  As of 20.12, the Swiss government pays for tests (both anti-gen and PCR tests) that are needed for a COVID-19 certificate.    Test costs for certificates will be covered again  The Federal Council has also decided that the costs of certain Covid-19 tests that lead to a Covid certificate will be covered again in future. In doing so, he is implementing a parliamentary decision in the Covid 19 law. Rapid antigen tests and saliva PCR pool tests are to be paid for. Self-tests, individual PCR tests and antibody tests are not paid for. The costs of individual PCR tests for people with symptoms of illness, for contact persons and after positive pool samples are also covered. The new test cost system will apply from tomorrow, Saturday, December 18, 2021. From January 17, 2022, everyone who takes part in repetitive tests must also be able to obtain a test certificate.    Only one test upon entry for vaccinated and recovered people  After consulting the cantons, the Federal Council has also adjusted the test regime upon entry, which will apply from Monday, December 20, 2021. Before entering Switzerland, in addition to PCR tests that are not are older than 72 hours, rapid antigen tests that are not older than 24 hours are also accepted. The obligation to have a second test 4 to 7 days after entering Switzerland is waived for vaccinated and recovered people.    http://web.archive.org/web/20211221065541/https://www.admin.ch/gov/de/start/dokumentation/medienmitteilungen.msg-id-86544.html

7/2/22  Entry where a certificate is required has strict criteria around the process placed upon venue owners.    Entry checks with the COVID certificate  When letting people in, it is important that event organisers check the validity of the COVID certificate via COVID Certificate Check and always check against matching photo identification (e.g. ID card, passport, driving licence, residence permit, student card). In addition, organisers of large-scale events must obtain a cantonal permit. The COVID certificate is the only permissible document for entry. This applies to both the Swiss COVID certificate and to recognised foreign certificates (e.g. the EU Digital COVID Certificate). Youâll find more information for checkers and issuers on the COVID certificate on the corresponding page.      https://web.archive.org/web/20220125075513/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html

Cyprus is changing its compulsory quarantine rules for school children in an effort to keep pupils in school amid surging coronavirus infections, the country's health minister said Wednesday.    Under the new system, schoolkids who were in close contact with classmates who test positive will no longer face compulsory quarantine. Instead, they must undergo either a rapid or a self-test for five consecutive days while continuing to attend school â so long as they test negative.    https://web.archive.org/https://abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory/cyprus-swaps-student-quarantine-days-virus-tests-82221285

Public events can take place, maximum of 1,000 spectators may be present. Spectators must be seated.   All spectators must have a respirator on at all times without an exhalation valve of min. class FFP2 (KN95 / N95).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214183933/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/culture/festivals

Public and private events can take place with a limit of 100 participants outdoors and indoors. If more than 20 people are present at the event, all those over 12 years of age must prove upon arrival either that they are vaccinated or that they have recovered from covid. Masks must be worn indoors.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220130141404/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/culture/social-events

Public and private events can take place with a limit of 100 participants.  During social events indoors, it is mandatory to wear a respirator without an exhalation valve min. class FFP2 (KN95 / N95).  If the event takes place outdoors, this obligation applies if the celebrations are attended by more than 30 people and at the same time it is not possible to keep a distance of at least 1.5 meters from other people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220214184126/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/culture/social-events

This compensation applies to cases where employees are ordered to quarantine or to be isolated due to COVID-19. The amount of the support is set at 80% of eligible costs (compensation of wages paid to employees + the corresponding amount of statutory contributions), but a maximum of CZK 39,000 per employee and month. For employees, this means that they are in obstacles and receive a wage compensation of 60% of average earnings.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220130144000/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/compensation/antivirus-plus-forced-limitations-service-operation-and-quarantine

Schoolchildren are back at their desks <> in Germany, with students in every state except Thuringia required to be present at in-person classes.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220104090933/https://www.thelocal.de/20220103/german-schools-start-up-against-as-omicron-cases-rise/  In Thuringia, Students who  do not participate in the specifically offered tests or who cannot provide proof of testing and who are not exempt from the obligation to participate in the specifically offered course  in accordance with <> are prohibited from entering the school building.  Distance learning takes place for these pupils,  in  which pupils are obliged to participate. This does not affect the containment of the spread of the coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 in day-care facilities ,other youth welfare, schools and sports operations. https://web.archive.org/web/20211229140809/https://bildung.thueringen.de/fileadmin/2021/2021-12-28_TMBJS_Allgemeinverfuegung_Kita-Schule-Jugendhilfe-Sport.pdf

Still restricted in at least one area. The general decree for the Free State of Thuringia for day-care facilities, schools, further youth welfare and for sport is valid until 20 February 2022. In the pdf it states that if children cannot be tested or are not vaccinated, then they are to remain home and use distance learning. As this does not apply to all levels, it is coded as a 2 rather than a 3. https://web.archive.org/web/20220204202503/https://bildung.thueringen.de/ministerium/coronavirus

2G rule also applies nationwide and regardless of incidence in the retail trade. Excluded are shops for daily needs. Access must be controlled by the shops.   In gastronomy (restaurants, cafÃ©s, bars and pubs, etc.), only vaccinated and convalescents should have access with a daily test or with a booster vaccination (from the day of the booster vaccination).  Indoor clubs and discotheques will remain closed until further notice and dance performances will be banned.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220126181506/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-regeln-und-einschrankungen-1734724  2G applies in retail shops, at cultural and leisure facilities (e.g. in restaurants, bars, hotels, theatres): Shops selling items for daily needs (e.g. supermarkets, pharmacies, drugstores, bookshops) remain open for everyone. A federal state can close restaurants or restrict hotel stays in a county if there is a high number of infections.  https://archive.vn/0kvjc#selection-8777.0-8779.90

In principle, entry is possible from: EU member states; states associated with Schengen: Iceland, Norway, Switzerland and Liechtenstein; other countries from which entry is possible in light of the epidemiological situation assessment by the EU.  Entry from any other country for any purpose (including visits and tourism)  is only possible for fully vaccinated People. The traveller must have received the last vaccination dose that is necessary for full vaccination at least 14 days before the date of travel, and the vaccine the person has received must be among those listed on the website of the Paul Ehrlich Institute.   For people not yet vaccinated entry from other countries is only possible in exceptional cases and is conditional on there being an urgent need.   Quarantine: Under the Ordinance on Coronavirus Entry Regulations, persons entering Germany following a stay in a high-risk area or area of variant of concern in the last ten days must proceed directly to their destination following entry and self-isolate there (quarantine). After a stay in a high-risk area travellers must self-isolate for 10 days, after a stay in an area of variant of concern for 14 days.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211224175315/https://www.auswaertiges-amt.de/en/visa-service/EinreiseUndAufenthalt#content_3

Persons entering must complete a digital entry registration. They also have to provide a negative test result or proof of immunity, and comply with quarantine regulations depending on the place of departure. A travel ban is in place for countries with widespread occurrence of SARS-CoV-2 virus variants of concern (referred to as areas of variant of concern).  https://web.archive.org/web/20220204204955/https://www.germany.info/us-en/coronavirus/2317268

Following the recommendation of the European Commission, the German authorities have decided to shorten the validity of vaccination certificates to 270 days.  The new rule on the vaccination passes entered into force on February 1 and affects everyone travelling within the EU. https://web.archive.org/web/20220207135111/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/new-rules-now-apply-for-entering-germany/
no changes since January: https://web.archive.org/web/20220211161808/https://www.auswaertiges-amt.de/en/coronavirus/2317268

In addition, newly founded companies that are less than five years old can make corona relief loans. In addition, newly founded companies that are less than five years old can make corona relief loans  https://web.archive.org/web/20220207150507/https://www.zusammengegencorona.de/informieren/arbeit-und-studium/arbeiten-und-corona/

The current short-time allowance regulation expires on 31 March. The Federal Cabinet has therefore initiated [updated] regulations will subsequently apply until 30 June 2022. The requirements for access to short-time allowance will remain reduced. https://web.archive.org/web/20220211155508/https://www.deutschland.de/en/news/german-federal-government-informs-about-the-corona-crisis

more generous repayment periods for Corona emergency aid (first program from spring 2020) are now possible. In addition, the repayment of loans (KfW entrepreneur loan, ERP start-up loan with liability exemption, KfW quick loan) remains flexible in the KfW special programme. Thus, the subsequent granting of a second repayment-free year for loans with only one repayment-free start-up year is still unbureaucratically possible and can be applied for via the respective house bank. The scheme, which was originally limited to 31.12.2021, has been extended until 17.06.2022 (application received by KfW). https://archive.vn/xXNzy

Residents of old people's homes and nursing homes, dormitories for people with disabilities and other particularly vulnerable groups require special protection. By 15 March 2022, employees of clinics, nursing homes and similar institutions must provide proof of vaccination or convalescence.  All visitors and employees must present a negative test certificate on a daily basis. This also applies to vaccinated people.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220204203141/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-regeln-und-einschrankungen-1734724
no changes until mandates take effect on 15 March: https://web.archive.org/web/20220211154243/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/corona-regeln-und-einschrankungen-1734724

There is general availability of the vaccine to people 12 and older. It is still noted that those people who have an increased risk of severe or fatal courses of a COVID-19 disease, for example due to old age or certain pre-existing conditions, received a vaccination [prioritized] offer. Furthermore, this included groups of people who are either particularly exposed professionally or have close contacts of vulnerable groups of people â for example, medical staff or nurses. The prioritization was introduced with a new version of the Coronavirus Vaccination Ordinance as of June 7, 2021, as most people in the prioritization groups had received a vaccination offer in the meantime. In the meantime, all citizens aged 12 and over can arrange a vaccination appointment. https://web.archive.org/web/20220128160650/https://www.zusammengegencorona.de/impfen/basiswissen-zum-impfen/die-nationale-impfstrategie/

National Vaccination Strategy was and is the basis for this. Among other things, it outlines the fair distribution of corona vaccines and the organization of the COVID-19 vaccination campaign in different phases and prioritizations: In the first phase, people at high risk and exposed parts of the population could be vaccinated â mainly in vaccination centers or by mobile vaccination teams. On 7 June 2021, vaccination priority was lifted in Germany. https://web.archive.org/web/20220207150507/https://www.zusammengegencorona.de/impfen/basiswissen-zum-impfen/die-nationale-impfstrategie/

Vaccines are generally available for people aged 12+. For five- to eleven-year-old children without pre-existing conditions, there is currently only a low risk of severe Covid-19 disease, hospitalization and intensive care. In addition, the risk of rare side effects of vaccination cannot currently be estimated due to the limited data available. Therefore, the STIKO does not currently issue a general vaccination recommendation for five- to eleven-year-old children without pre-existing conditions. https://web.archive.org/web/20220128155639/https://www.bundesregierung.de/breg-de/themen/coronavirus/coronavirus-impfung-faq-1788988  Recent guidance does call out the 50+ year old low vaccination rate as a risk, while agreeing to continue the measures taken so far & intensify their vaccination campaign this month: https://web.archive.org/web/20220126181808/https:/www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/974430/2000838/196ba96d5c9f415faf48dbb9178fc24f/2022-01-24-mpk-beschluss-data.pdf?download=1

all citizens aged 12 and over can arrange a vaccination appointment: https://web.archive.org/web/20220207150507/https://www.zusammengegencorona.de/impfen/basiswissen-zum-impfen/die-nationale-impfstrategie/

Vaccination is easily available everywhere at no cost.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220126181808/https:/www.bundesregierung.de/resource/blob/974430/2000838/196ba96d5c9f415faf48dbb9178fc24f/2022-01-24-mpk-beschluss-data.pdf?download=1

The federal government procures and finances all vaccines used in Germany. https://web.archive.org/web/20220207150507/https://www.zusammengegencorona.de/impfen/basiswissen-zum-impfen/die-nationale-impfstrategie/

While in school, Children and parents who have symptoms of COVID-19 are encouraged to follow the general recommendation to keep children home from school and get tested immediately. Pupils from 1st grade onwards and staff in primary and lower secondary school are strongly encouraged to get tested on a weekly basis, unless they are fully vaccinated or previously infected with COVID-19 within the last 12 weeks.      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220120181034/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

While in school, Children and parents who have symptoms of COVID-19 are encouraged to follow the general recommendation to keep children home from school and get tested immediately. Pupils from 1st grade onwards and staff in primary and lower secondary school are strongly encouraged to get tested on a weekly basis, unless they are fully vaccinated or previously infected with COVID-19 within the last 12 weeks.      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220120181034/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

There are no restrictions from February 1, but there are a number of recommendations to prevent infection. People with symptoms of COVID-19 are advised to self-isolate and be PCR-tested as soon as possible. Pupils with symptoms of COVID-19 should be kept separate from the other students and staff until they can be picked up or sent home.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220210053301/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

It is adviced to work at home extensively in both public and private workplaces and that meetings, seminars etc. are held virtually.  It is adviced to cancel major social events at workplaces.  Discos and nightclubs are closed. Bars must close at 11pm    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220120181034/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

It is adviced to work at home extensively in both public and private workplaces and that meetings, seminars etc. are held virtually.  It is adviced to cancel major social events at workplaces.  Discos and nightclubs are closed. Bars must close at 11pm    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220120181034/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

There are no longer any recommendations to work from home in either public or private workplaces. Public and private employers are encouraged to continuously assess the situation and arrange the workplaces according to local infection conditions and the physical conditions in the workplace.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220210053301/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

A corona passport or similar must be presented if there is access for more than 100 people indoor and 1000 people outdoor in an event    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220120181034/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations
NA

There is no assembly ban or any restrictions on how many spectators may attend cultural and sporting events. Organizers of activities where many people gather standing indoors at the same time, and where there may therefore be a particularly high risk of the spread of infection, may consider taking steps to minimize the risk of infection in February. For an example this can be done by the organizer encouraging or facilitating that the participants are tested, or that an increased distance is operated at the event.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220210053301/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

For people entering Denmark from an EU and / or Schengen country or COVID-19 risk country, there is no requirement for isolation after entry.    However, those entering from a COVID-19 high-risk country must self-isolate after entry, unless they are fully vaccinated or previously infected. The isolation is required for 10 days but the isolation may be ended after a negative PCR test taken at the earliest on the sixth day after the time of entry.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220120183111/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/covidtravelrules

People are fully vaccinated or previously infected and able to document this, for example with a corona passport,  can enter from all countries without test or self-isolation.    FOR THE UNVACCINATED OR THOSE WHO WERE PREVIOUSLY UNINFECTED:    - Entry from countries in EU/Schengen: A test must be taken within 24 hours after entry.    - Entry from COVID-19 risk countries: A test must be taken within 24 hours after entry.    - Entry from all other countries (high risk countries): A test must be taken within 24 hours after entry within 24 hours after entry. Furthermore, there is self-isolation for 10 days. The isolation may be ended with a negative PCR-test taken at least six days after arrival. Certain travellers (e.g. children under 15) are exempt from test and isolation requirements.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220210053540/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/covidtravelrules

From 1 February 2022 there are no longer any restrictions in the social and elderly area. Thus there are no longer a requirement for corona passport for visitors etc. and requirements for the use of face mask or shield for visitors, etc. and employees on social services, etc.     If possible it is urged to continue arrangements for the display of corona passport and for the use of face mask/shield in nursing homes and social services with vulnerable residents/users. It is also urged with a continued focus on the test effort in relation to employees in the elderly care and on social services as well as visitors to nursing homes and social services.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220210053301/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

Distance Learning is recommended. Social distancing measures and masks are recommended in formal and informal education. Participants in informal education, hobby activities, refresher training and youth work who are over 18 years of age have to present a valid COVID certificate proving vaccination or recovery. Otherwise, participants may need to present with a medical certificate affirming that vaccination is contraindicated to the person for health reasons.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220130230356/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/education-pre-schools-hobby-education-sport-continuous-education/restrictions-in-education-youth-work-hobby-and-sports-activities  http://web.archive.org/web/20220130231531/https://kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/levels-risk

In general education, masks are recommended but covid-certificates are not mandatory.  In informal education and catering establishments, students must either be vaccinated, recovered or present a negative test (tests are accepted only for those under 18).   https://web.archive.org/web/20220211105524/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/education-pre-schools-hobby-education-sport-continuous-education/restrictions-in-education-youth-work-hobby-and-sports-activities

Since January 27th 2022, the country went into very high risk level for covid-19 which means that distance working is highly recommended, in addition to the previous existing measures.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220130231121/https://www.kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions#distants  http://web.archive.org/web/20220130231531/https://kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/levels-risk

All persons 18 years of age and older must present a COVID certificate proving vaccination or recovery in order to participate in activities taking place in checked public spaces. A COVID certificate has to be presented to participate in sports, training, youth work, hobby activities and informal education, refresher training; at sports competitions, and sports and exercise events; in saunas, spas, water parks and swimming pools; at public meetings and events, including at the theatre, at the cinema, at a concert (including a church concert), at a conference; at museums and exhibition facilities; at entertainment services; at catering establishments in order to eat and drink on the premises.    For everyone, masks are mandatory in public spaces indoors and distance working is recommended.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220130231121/https://www.kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions

Non-vaccinated:   If vaccination is contraindicated to a person for health reasons, a corresponding medical certificate needs to be presented in order to participate.    Vaccinated:   Public meetings and events are allowed but participants who are 18 years old and older have to present a COVID certificate stating vaccination or recovery. Young people from the age of 12 years and three months up to 17 years (included) have to present a certificate proving vaccination or recovery or a certificate proving a negative result of a PCR or antigen RT test done by a health care service provider in order to participate.    Provided that the organiser ensures that the infection risk status of all the participants is checked, up to 1000 people may participate indoors and up to 2 000 people outdoors.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220130231121/https://www.kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions#distants

Public meetings and events are allowed but participants who are 18 years old and older have to prove that they do not pose an infection risk by presenting a COVID certificate stating vaccination or recovery.  For children of 12 of 18, negative tests are accepted for their COVID certificate.  Provided that the organiser ensures that the infection risk status of all the participants is checked, up to 1000 people may participate indoors and up to 2 000 people outdoors.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220211105944/https://www.kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions

Recommendations are made to protect elderly people.   Where possible, home-based services provided for the elderly by the local government of residence should be preferred to placement in a nursing home.  Residents of nursing homes should not be transferred between different homes.  Before meeting a person at risk, make sure you are safe from infection and ensure safety when meeting them: wear a mask, keep your distance, and clean your hands and surfaces.    https://archive.ph/Z6tPJ

The Nationwide Telework recommendation has now been reintroduced in areas currently experiencing increased levels of community transmission.   The recommendation is for all employees in the public sector to work remotely as extensively as possible if their duties so allow. The Government also recommends that private employers adopt similar extensive remote work practices, recognising, however, that workplaces will determine how to combine in-office and remote work in a way that ensures health security.     Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211216145328/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/-/10623/government-recommends-remote-work-in-areas-in-the-community-transmission-phase-until-further-notice

The requirements for entry into Finland include the following:   - a certificate of a full approved COVID-19 vaccination series, OR  - a certificate of having had the COVID-19 disease and one approved COVID-19 vaccine, OR  - an EU Digital COVID Certificate for a COVID-19 disease had less than six months ago, AND  - a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test taken no earlier than 48 hours before arrival in Finland.    These requirements apply to those born in or before 2006. They however do not apply to citizens of Finland, those with permanent residence in Finland or persons travelling for essential reasons. Those who do not meet the requirement are required to have a mandatory covid test.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220106182331/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic

A mobile app "Koronavilkku",  is a contact tracing app was produced by the Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) to help people find out whether you may have been exposed to coronavirus. The app can also be used to send share positive tests results anonymously with those you have been in close contact with.      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210820141655/https://koronavilkku.fi/en

The Finnish Institute of Health and Welfare recommends a third dose of coronavirus vaccine for    - persons with severe immunodeficiency and aged 12 or over  - persons who have been vaccinated with a short interval of less than 6 weeks and are aged 18 or over  all persons aged 60 and over  - persons living in institutions and care homes and aged 18 or over  - persons in medical high-risk groups 1 and 2 and aged 18 or over health care personnel who treat coronavirus patients, personnel of 24-hour care facilities and other social welfare and health care personnel providing urgent care. Covid-19 protocols in schools have been simplified in order to allow education facilities to remain open. The following regulations, announced by the Prime Minister on 10 January, take effect as of 14 January:     - When a positive case is detected in a class, parents will no longer be asked to pick up their child immediately, they can wait for the end of the school day.  - When a positive case is detected in a classroom, case contacts aged under 12 years or those aged over 12 who have a complete vaccination schedule will be able to use 3 free self-tests provided by pharmacies, and will no longer have to perform a PCR or antigen test followed by two self-tests).  - Parents will no longer be asked to produce a certificate after each self-test: a single certificate will be requested. Children may not attend school if one of the self-tests is positive.     Additional measures were announced by the Minister of Education, Youth and Sports on 13 January, including:     - the distribution of 5 million FFP2 masks in establishments for staff who feel the need;  - the replenishment of the fund for the purchase of CO2 sensors as much as necessary, so that local authorities can request it even more massively.  - the recruitment of 3,300 more contract workers;  - the use of supplementary lists;  - the recruitment of educational assistants and support staff for school principals.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220114193949/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education
No policy changes - https://web.archive.org/web/20220121172851/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

No change in policy. It was announced that baccalaureate specialty exams, scheduled for March 14 to 16, are postponed to May 11, 12 and 13 due to the Covid-19 epidemic.    - https://web.archive.org/web/20220115062509/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education    Use of the "Vaccine Pass" is not required to access schools or educational facilities - https://web.archive.org/web/20220128182239/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

No change in policy, a Vaccine Pass is not required to access schools or other educational facilities (although any outing for a non-usual activity (e.g. school trip to the cinema), involving a mix with the public, requires the presentation of a "health pass" since September 30 for students aged 12 and two months and over (school, colleges, high schools) and in Universities, the "health pass" is not required to access courses, and can only apply to certain festive, cultural, sports and educational activities welcoming external participants or whose number is more than 50 people.) - https://web.archive.org/web/20220206173803/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20220206173803/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

No change in policy, but it was announced that discotheques and nightclubs will be allowed to re-open and standing concerts will be allowed from 16 February  - https://web.archive.org/web/20220122111845/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Discotheques and nightclubs are currently closed, but will be allowed to re-open and standing concerts will be allowed from 16 February  - https://web.archive.org/web/20220128182452/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus    All healthcare workers, and administrative and ancillary staff working for healthcare providers, home helps, are subject to mandatory vaccination - https://web.archive.org/web/20220128203947/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-vaccinal    Additionally, from 24 January the "Health Pass" has been replaced by the "Vaccine Pass" for all people aged 16 and over. A vaccination pass is required for all employees and customers/visitors to:     - places of entertainment and leisure (cinemas, museums, theatres, sports and entertainment venues, libraries, and others)  - bars and restaurants;  - long-distance/inter-regioanl transport by plane, train or bus  - fairs, professional seminars and exhibitions  - stores and shopping centres (depending on the decision of the prefect)    https://web.archive.org/web/20220128203947/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-vaccinal

A vaccination pass is required for all employees and customers/visitors to:     - places of entertainment and leisure (cinemas, museums, theatres, sports and entertainment venues, libraries, and others)  - bars and restaurants;  - long-distance/inter-regioanl transport by plane, train or bus  - fairs, professional seminars and exhibitions  - stores and shopping centres (depending on the decision of the prefect)    https://web.archive.org/web/20220205235228/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-vaccinal

No change in policy - discotheques and nightclubs remain closed, but will be allowed to re-open on 16 February. Standing concerts are also prohibitied until that date.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220209213558/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus    A Vaccine Pass is required for all employees and customers/visitors to:     - places of entertainment and leisure (cinemas, museums, theatres, sports and entertainment venues, libraries, and others)  - bars and restaurants;  - long-distance/inter-regioanl transport by plane, train or bus  - fairs, professional seminars and exhibitions  - stores and shopping centres (depending on the decision of the prefect)    the Vaccine Pass applies to all people aged 16 and over, and proves that the bearer has either completed a full vaccination schedule, has recovered from Covid-19 in the past 6 months, or has contraindications for vaccination. From 15 February, the rules relating to the Vaccination Pass are changing for people over 18 years and 1 month of age. The booster dose should be carried out as early as 3 months after the end of its initial vaccination schedule and within a maximum of 4 months.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220210095345/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-vaccinal

From 24 January, the classification of countries on the 3-stage system of Green/Orange/Red has been adjusted with some countires and territories moving from Red or Green status to Orange. Countries of the travellers origin are categorised as follows:     "Green" countries/territories: countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, South Korea, the United Arab Emirates, Hong Kong, Japan, Kuwait, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Senegal, Taiwan, Uruguay and Vanuatu. (previously, Argentina and Australia were on the Green list, but have moved to Orange)    "Orange" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries/territories. Reinforced measures are in force for travel between France and the United Kingdom. The Travel Advice sheet for the United Kingdom should be consulted.    "Red" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus with the presence of variants of concern is observed. These are: Afghanistan, Belarus, the United States, Georgia, Mauritius, Montenegro, Nigeria, Pakistan, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Suriname, Tanzania, Turkey. (previously, Botswana, Lesotho, Malawi, Moldova, Mozambique, Namibia, Russia, South Africa, Ukraine, Zambia and Zimbabwe were on the Red list, and have now moved to Orange)    All passengers from Red list countries must present negative results of a PCR or antigen test taken in the previous 48 hours at boarding and may be tested again on arrival. Unvaccinated passengers are subject to presentation of "compelling reasons" for travel, mandatory antigen testing on arrival, and must quarantine for 10 days under the control of security forces.     Passengers from Orange list countries must present negative results of a PCR or antigen test taken in the previous 48 hours at boarding. Vaccinated passengers are not subject to the "compelling reasons" regime, but unvaccinated people are and must commit to self-isolation lasting 7 days and undergo testing at the end of this period.     Although an Orange list country, additional regulations apply to all passengers aged 12 or over arriving from the United Kingdom from 14 January:     - All travelers, vaccinated or not, must present a negative test (PCR or antigen test) taken less than 24 hours before travel  - For vaccinated travellers, there is no longer any obligation to justify a compelling reason to come to France, nor an obligation to respect a period of isolation on arrival on the national territory. As such, the need to register, prior to travel, on the digital platform "eOS passenger" is lifted. Screenings on arrival may be conducted at the places of arrival. In the event of a positive result, the traveller will be placed in solitary confinement.  - For unvaccinated travellers, travel to or from the United Kingdom is permitted provided that it can prove compelling reasons valid for "red" countries.  - Unvaccinated travellers from the United Kingdom must continue to register, before their departure, on the eOS passenger digital platform, allowing them to enter the address of their stay in France. They must, upon arrival in France, observe a strict quarantine period of 10 days at this place; this quarantine will be controlled by law enforcement.    Specific guidance for UK passengers is available at https://web.archive.org/web/20220117202519/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/deplacements#voyager_dans_l'union_europeenne    Passengers from Green List countries are divided into two groups:     1. Member States of the European Union, Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, the Holy See and Switzerland - Travelers twelve years of age or older who do not have proof of a complete vaccination schedule or a certificate of recovery from Covid-19 must present before travel the negative result of a test (PCR or antigenic) of less than 24 hours. They may be tested for antigen on arrival.    2. Bahrain, Hong Kong, Japan, Kuwait, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, South Korea, Taiwan, The United Arab Emirates, Uruguay and Vanuatu:  All travelers twelve years of age or older, regardless of their vaccination status,from these countries/territories must present for boarding, the negative result of a PCR test or an antigen test (TAG) carried out less than 48 hours before the flight. They may be tested for antigen on arrival.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220128204055/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20220131221438/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/deplacements

From 4 February, the classification of countries from which travelers are subject to differentiated border controls based on health indicators is as follows:     - "Green" countries and territories: countries or territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, South Korea, the United Arab Emirates, Honduras, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Kuwait, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Senegal, Taiwan, Uruguay*, Vanuatu.  *Uruguay will move from the Green List to the Orange List as of February 6, 2022.  - "Orange" countries: countries in which there is an active circulation of the virus in controlled proportions, without diffusion of worrying variants. These are not all countries included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries.  - "Red" countries: countries in which active circulation of the virus is observed with the presence of variants of concern. To date, there are no countries classified as "red".  - "Scarlet red" countries: countries in which a particularly active circulation of the virus and the discovery of a variant likely to present a risk of increased transmissibility or immune escape are observed. To date, there is no country classified as "scarlet red".    Anyone aged 12 and over entering French territory must present a negative PCR or antigen test of less than 24 hours or 48 hours depending on the country of origin. The only exception is that people with a complete vaccination schedule do not have to be tested when arriving from a Member State of the European Union, Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, the Holy See or Switzerland.    Specific rules in place for travel to and from the UK were relaxed on 4 February from those implemented in January. As of this date, travelers from the UK are included in the provisions of travelers from the list of Orange countries, with the nuance that unvaccinated travelers from the UK must provide results of a PCR or antigen test taken within 24 hours of travel, and within 48 hours for vaccinated travelers.     - https://web.archive.org/web/20220205210857/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/deplacements     1/ travelers from a country/territory classified as "green"  1.1: for the Member States of the European Union, Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, the Holy See and Switzerland:  Travelers twelve years of age or older who do not have proof of a complete vaccination schedule or a certificate of recovery from Covid-19 must present before travel the negative result of a test (PCR or antigenic) of less than 24 hours. They may be tested for antigen on arrival.    This obligation does not apply to the travel of road transport professionals in the exercise of their activity and to the following trips by land:    Journeys of less than 24 hours within a perimeter defined by a radius of 30 kilometres around the place of residence;  Business travel whose urgency or frequency is incompatible with the performance of a test or screening examination.  1.2: for Bahrain, Honduras, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Kuwait, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, South Korea, Taiwan, United Arab Emirates and Vanuatu:  All travellers twelve years of age or older, regardless of their vaccination status, from these countries/territories must present a negative PCR test or antigen test (GAD) taken less than 48 hours before the flight for boarding. They may be tested for antigen on arrival.    2/ travellers from a country/territory classified as "orange": all countries/territories other than those mentioned in paragraph 1 ("green")    - All travellers twelve years of age or older, regardless of their vaccination status, must present a negative PCR test or antigen test (GAD) taken less than 48 hours before the flight. For unvaccinated travellers from the UK, the time to complete the PCR or antigenic test is 24 hours.    All travelers will be eligible for an antigen test upon arrival. In addition:    - vaccinated travellers (full vaccination schedule) are not subject to the regime of compelling reasons.  - unvaccinated travellers are subject to the imperative grounds regime and will have to commit to a 7-day self-isolation and undergo a test at the end of this period. The list of compelling reasons is specified in the travel and travel certificate issued by the Ministry of the Interior. Under this list, the following may enter France: the French, their spouses and children, nationals of the European area as well as their spouses and children having their main residence in France or who join, in transit through France, their main residence in a country of the European area or the country of which they are nationals.    - https://web.archive.org/web/20220205235349/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

From 6 February, Uruguay moves from the Green to the Orange list. There are no other policy changes. https://web.archive.org/web/20220211172530/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

Policies relating to the allowances paid to employers whose employees are obliged to reduce the number of hours worked were updated for the period 28 January to 28 February 22, providing:     - 36% of the employee's previous gross salary within the limit of 4.5 SMIC with a floor of â¬7.53    - 70% of the employee's previous gross remuneration (i.e. approximately 84% of the net salary), within the limit of a remuneration of 4.5 SMIC, with a floor of â¬8.37 per hour, regardless of the company's workforce  -- in establishments open to the public and closed by administrative decision to combat the spread of the covid19 epidemic  --in establishments located in a reconfined territory when they suffer a 60% loss of turnover either in relation to the turnover recorded during the month preceding the implementation of the reconfinement, or in relation to the turnover recorded for the same month in 2019.  -- for employers belonging to so-called protected sectors (S1, S1 Bis) and which suffer a decrease in turnover of at least 65 % compared to the turnover recorded for the same month in 2020 or 2019, in respect of the turnover achieved over the previous six months compared to the same period in 2019, compared to the average monthly turnover achieved in 2019 or, for companies created after 30 June 2020, in relation to the average monthly turnover achieved between the date of creation of the company and 30 june 2021 (before 1er December 2021, this drop in turnover had to be at least 80%) or subject to health restrictions. These companies can benefit from the partial activity scheme without any remaining expenses. The derogation of partial activity without remaining at the expense of these employers is renewed.    - https://web.archive.org/web/20220211172553/https://www.economie.gouv.fr/covid19-soutien-entreprises/dispositif-de-chomage-partiel    There are no changes to the policies supporting the self-employed - https://web.archive.org/web/20220211172612/https://www.economie.gouv.fr/covid19-soutien-entreprises/reponses-gouvernement-difficultes-independants

PCR and antigen tests are widely available, per the US Embassy in France:     - Antigen test results are available within 24 hours, often in less than one hour. PCR test results may take up to 48 hours.   - Numerous pharmacies offer rapid antigen tests on a walk-in basis. To locate pharmacies open after-hours, weekends, or holidays in Paris and outskirts visit https://web.archive.org/web/20220206184330/https://monpharmacien-idf.fr/?. To find late-night or emergency pharmacies anywhere in France, call 112 (European emergency number, available free of charge, 24/7).  - PCR testing is available?at many?laboratories and testing centers, usually by appointment â including the testing centers at?Parisâ airports.   - Antigen tests cost 25 Euros, payable in advance.?PCR tests cost 43.89 Euros. As of October 15 [2021], free COVID tests?at public testing centers?for French residents?are no longer available, with an exception for fully vaccinated residents or residents with a prescription.?Private testing centers, including pharmacies, may charge. COVID test results can be obtained on paper, or via email or SMS message.?     - https://web.archive.org/web/20220205235318/https://fr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Government policy is described at https://web.archive.org/web/20220205235520/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/tests-et-depistage

Vaccination is universally available to people aged 5 and over.     Vaccination boosters are available to all people aged 18 and over from three months after the last injection or infection with Covid-19. From 24 January, booster vaccinations will be available to everyone aged 12 and over.     People aged 80 and over are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220123183741/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

Vaccination is universally available to people aged 5 and over.     From 24 January, vaccination boosters are available to all people aged 12 and over from three months after the last injection or infection with Covid-19. Prior to this date, booster vaccinations were available to everyone aged 18 and over.     People aged 80 and over are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220128204853/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

Vaccination is universally available to people aged 5 and over, with one parent's permission required for children aged between 5 and 11.     Vaccination boosters are available to all people aged 12 and over from three months after the last injection or infection with Covid-19.    People aged 80 and over are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     Vaccination is mandatory for all those who work in contact with frail people. Thus, since September 15, 2021, the following must be vaccinated:    - all staff (including administrative staff) of health institutions, medico-social institutions (EHPAD, USLD, autonomous residences, disability structures with or without accommodation and including non-medicalized), social institutions attached to a health institution (LHSS, LAM, CSAPA, CAARUD, CLAT, CEGGID);  - home helpers working with people affecting APA or PCH, in home services or as employees of individual employers;  - staff of medical transport companies (including taxis under agreement);  - all professions in Book IV of the CSP, whether or not under agreement, and professions for the use of titles, as well as their employees (e.g. medical secretaries, dental assistants);  - all health students;  - SDIS-Firefighters (professionals and volunteers);  - occupational health service personnel.  - Persons justifying a contraindication to vaccination are exempt from the vaccination obligation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220206174049/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

The Chief Medical Officer will contact you if you have been in direct contact with an infected person. If you have had direct contact with a person who has been infected with COVID-19 you will quarantine for at least 10 days, pending a negative test result.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211222162315/https://korona.fo/270?_l=en

As of February 1, 2022:  Quarantine rules will be eased:  Close contacts should go into quarantine. England's Plan B measures are to end from Thursday 27 January. Covid passports dropped meaning all businesses are open, without any requirement to present a pass to get in. Mandatory Covid passports for entering nightclubs and large events would end, though organisations could choose to use the NHS Covid pass if they wished. People would no longer be advised to work from home and should discuss their return to offices with employers  Face masks will no longer be mandated, though people are still advised to wear coverings in enclosed or crowded spaces and when meeting strangers.    Covid passes still required in other devolved nations for access to some businesses so coding remains at a 2, but now Targeted not General    http://web.archive.org/web/20220121121233/https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-60047438

In Northern Ireland 'No more than 30 people can meet in a private home and stay overnight. Regulations remain in place that prevent gatherings/ parties of more than 30 people in domestic settings.'    https://archive.vn/rXYXV

Northern Ireland- recommendations remain in place    Travel  You should avoid visiting places where there is a chance that large numbers of people will gather and crowds will form.  If you go somewhere and there are crowds which will make social distancing difficult, consider going somewhere else instead.  When travelling you should walk, cycle or use private transport, shared only with members of your household where possible.  If possible, you should avoid car sharing with people from outside of your household. If you are car sharing, as well as wearing a face covering, good ventilation in the car is vitally important - particularly by keeping a window open.    https://archive.vn/rXYXV

Changes to be introduced 11 February for fully vaccinated travellers    Mr Speaker, from 4am on the 11th February, and in time for the half-term break, eligible fully vaccinated passengers arriving in the UK will no longer have to take a post-arrival, lateral flow test.    Today I can announce that passengers who do not qualify as fully vaccinated will no longer be required to do a day 8 test after arrival or, indeed, to self-isolate. They will still need to fill out a passenger locator form to demonstrate proof of a negative COVID test taken 2 days before travel, and they must also take a post-arrival PCR test.      https://archive.vn/FNxIc

Public and private schools in Georgia resumed in-person studies following winter holidays on January 17.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220130201314/https://agenda.ge/en/news/2022/211  Facemask use mandatory for all students.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220130173058/https://stopcov.gov.ge/en/page/restrictions-list
Public and private schools in Georgia resumed in-person studies following winter holidays on January 17. Facemask use mandatory for all students.   https://archive.vn/GWEwD  https://archive.vn/VQDKH

Public institutions are instructed to move their staff onto the remote format of work to the maximum extent possible and similar recommendation is given by the Council to employers in the private sector.  In line with a decision made by the Coordination Council, citizens of Georgia will be allowed to enter the following facilities with a Green Passport from December 1, 2021: indoor or outdoor eateries, restaurants, cafes and bars; cinemas, theatres, operas, museums, concert halls, entertainment centers, casinos and gambling centers; spas, fitness centers, hotels and cable lifts of ski resorts. The referred requirement will apply to visitors of the listed facilities. As for the entertainment centers for children, Green Passport will be required from citizens aged 18 and older. An individual will have a green status, if s/he is vaccinated, has a PCR test valid for 72 hours or antigen test valid for 24 hours or has been infected with a novel coronavirus. Night clubs remain banned both outdoors and indoors.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220130173058/https://stopcov.gov.ge/en/page/restrictions-list

Public institutions are instructed to move their staff onto the remote format of work to the maximum extent possible and a similar recommendation is given by the Council to employers in the private sector.  https://archive.vn/VQDKH

Restriction remains valid on holding the wide-scale entertainment and such social events, as wedding parties, banquets, jubilees of various types and similar. Eateries and ritual venues of miscellaneous types will be sanctioned with 10 000 GEL for hosting such events but will be sealed if found in breach of the regulation for the second time. Night clubs remain banned both outdoors and indoors.  Any type of entertainment activities, arts and culture events (except for stage performances and cinema), festivals are going to be fully banned. The referred restriction does not apply to concerts to be held at the premises of hotels. As for sports tournaments of various types, they may be held without spectators. Nevertheless, every participant should be vaccinated (14 days should be lapsed from the second dose) or have a PCR test result obtained in the past 72 hours or a negative result of an antigen test obtained in the past 24 hours.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220130173058/https://stopcov.gov.ge/en/page/restrictions-list

Border crossing is currently permitted to citizens of EU member states and 40 countries   in addition, as well as to individuals with a permission of residence. They need to present the following at the border crossing: document evidencing a full cycle of vaccination and a negative result of PCR test obtained in the past 72 hours, or alternatively present only a negative PCR test result obtained 72 hours prior to the visit to Georgia and get a repeated PCR test on the 3rd day of their stay in Georgia at their own expense.  When entering the country, foreign nationals who have had COVID-19 and are vaccinated with one dose, will be subject to the same regulation as applicable to individuals vaccinated with both doses.  Georgian citizens vaccinated in Georgia and entering the country through land borders are exempt from mandatory PCR testing.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220130173058/https://stopcov.gov.ge/en/page/restrictions-list  Mandatory 14-day quarantine, followed by a PCR test is imposed on anyone who has been in South Africa, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Namibia, Lesotho, Eswatini, Mozambique or Malawi in the previous 14-day period.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220130181211/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/georgia/entry-requirements

Foreign citizens arriving by air may be unconditionally admitted to Georgia if they present a COVID-19 vaccine certificate confirming receipt of two full doses of the vaccine (or one dose in the case of the Johnson & Johnson vaccine).    The requirement to self-isolate is terminated for unvaccinated visitors who are citizens or residents of the United States (and several other listed countries) and meet the listed requirements.     Travelers arriving by land or sea must be citizens or residents of listed countries and travel must be directly from a listed country (including Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Turkey), including transit through third countries.        Vaccinated travelers must present BOTH proof of vaccination and a negative PCR test result conducted 72 hours or less before arrival in Georgia (see above for details).  No follow-up PCR test is required.     Unvaccinated travelers must comply with the same requirements for unvaccinated travelers who arrive by air .  https://archive.fo/KHpr1

Greece will reopen schools as scheduled on Monday amid record coronavirus cases, the government has decided.    Schools will reopen on Jan. 10 with stricter testing protocols as ânothing can replace live teaching for the psycho-emotional development of our children,â Education Minister Niki Kerameus said Tuesday.    https://web.archive.org/web/%2A/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-01-04/greece-to-reopen-schools-as-planned-on-monday-amid-record-cases

Greece reintroduced measures aimed at curbing the spread of the coronavirus pandemic amid concern that rising cases will pile pressure on the nationâs health care system.    As much as 50% of all private and public-sector employees will have to work from home between Jan. 3 and Jan. 16, Health Minister Athanasios Plevris said Monday. The government also ordered restaurants, bars, cafes and night clubs to close at midnight.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220110161816/https://www.bloomberg.com/tosv2.html?vid=&uuid=ea7e0e9d-7230-11ec-a53d-5a7175777570&url=L25ld3MvYXJ0aWNsZXMvMjAyMS0xMi0yNy9ncmVlY2UtcmVpbnN0YXRlcy13b3JrLWZyb20taG9tZS1tYW5kYXRlLW5pZ2h0LWxpZmUtY3VyYnM=

no policy change     Unless all passengers are members of the same family, a maximum of 3 persons are permitted to travel in a taxi or other private vehicle with up to 7 seats, or 4 persons in a private vehicle with up to 9 seats;  Cross-regional travel is allowed for mainland Greece and the islands of Lefkada, Evia and Salamina (use of self-tests ahead of travel is strongly recommended but is not mandatory).  Cross-regional travel to the rest of the islands is permitted but only with either:    proof of vaccination and 14 days since second dose (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status), or  a negative result from a PCR test carried out up to 72 hours prior to travel; or  a negative result from a rapid test or self-test conducted up to 24 hours before travel; or  a self-test declaration signed less than 24 hours before travel; or  documentary proof of having recovered from Covid-19 (at least 2 months since infection, and no more than 9 months)  Travel in Greece  Travel within Greece between Regional Units is permitted subject to adherence to public health measures as outlined above. You must wear a mask at all times on all public transport.    If you are travelling via ferry, you will need to complete a health questionnaire and hand it to the ferry operator before boarding. The necessary forms will be provided by the operator: you should contact them directly if you need further information. Temperature checks may also be carried out before boarding.    If you are travelling by internal (domestic) flights, specific measures relating to check-in, baggage allowances and other details are in place to reduce the spread of coronavirus. You should check with your operator directly for further detail.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210802101710/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus
