21/1/22  Social distance and face masks  Restrictions on movement  1.5 meters - the minimum distance between pedestrians  Obligation to maintain a distance of at least 1.5 meters between pedestrians.    The following are excluded from this obligation:    parents with children requiring care (up to 13 years of age),  people living together or running a farm,  people with a disability certificate, people with a disability degree, people with a certificate of need for special education, people who are unable to move independently and their guardians.  Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  The nose and mouth may only be covered with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / client service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    Important! Only persons with a medical certificate or a document confirming:    pervasive development disorders,  mental disorders,  moderate, severe or severe intellectual disability,  difficulty uncovering or covering your mouth or nose on your own.  advanced neurological, respiratory or circulatory disorders with respiratory or circulatory failure.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220121112908/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

21/1/22  Important! From January 11 to January 24, flights are banned from Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa and Zimbabwe.    People returning from these countries cannot be released from quarantine for 14 days.    The provisions on quarantine do not apply to people who have:    EU digital COVID certification for COVID-19 vaccination, COVID-19 infection or negative COVID-19 test;  certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery due to COVID-19 recognized as equivalent to the EU COVID Certificate.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220121113541/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/granice-i-ruch-miedzynarodowy

Also an increase to the threshold that triggers for individual taxpayers, application of the higher income tax bracket of 32% to PLN 120,000 (currently PLN 85,528), and an increase to the total tax and contribution burden for non-deductible health insurance contributions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211201130444/https://home.kpmg/us/en/home/insights/2021/05/tnf-poland-proposed-economic-stimulus-plan-tax-measures.html

Broad range of contract relief policies seem to be in place as of 08 August.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210808083453/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/informacje-dla-beneficjentow-fe    Further, Poland's government on 15 May 2021 unveiled details about a new stimulus plan designed to bolster the economy following the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic.    The proposed program introduced amendments to the Polish tax system, including changes affecting individual taxpayers such as:    An increase to income for the âtax-free allowanceâ for low-wage earners  An increase to the threshold that triggers for individual taxpayers, application of the higher income tax bracket of 32% to PLN 120,000 (currently PLN 85,528)  An increase to the total tax and contribution burden for non-deductible health insurance contributions    https://web.archive.org/web/20211201130444/https://home.kpmg/us/en/home/insights/2021/05/tnf-poland-proposed-economic-stimulus-plan-tax-measures.html

Can a test referral only be issued by a GP? Can a doctor from night and holiday telephoto issue such a referral?  An order for a coronavirus test can be issued by a doctor on duty as part of night or holiday health care.    You can also sign up for an online test. All you have to do is fill in the form available at gov.pl/dom . You will be asked to answer a few questions. Based on the data you provide, the system will determine if you qualify for the test.    How it's working?    Go to gov.pl/dom and click the "Form" button.  Answer the survey questions.  If the system qualifies you for the test, a consultant from the Home Medical Care Monitoring Center will contact you.  You will receive an order for the test from the eKolejka system.    https://archive.fo/wXmsk

6/2/22    Change in policy. Test are now available for anyone at a pharmacy without prior registration    How to get a coronavirus test at a pharmacy  No signups, no long waiting times and free of charge - now you can get tested at the pharmacy if you are concerned that you have the coronavirus. Check in which pharmacies near you can make it and on what terms!    In the pharmacy, you can do an antigen test:    without prior registration;  free;  unlimited - as many times as you need,  fast - the result after only a dozen or so minutes!  How to do it  Come to the pharmacy where the tests are performed - but be careful! Not every pharmacy participates in the program. Find out where the nearest pharmacy that runs the tests is .  The pharmacist will take a swab.  After a dozen or so minutes, you will receive the result and the pharmacist will enter it in the system.  You can also find information about the result on the Internet Patient Account and in the mojeIKP application .  Test results  If your score is:    negative - you will receive the EU COVID Certificate after the antigen test (valid for 48 hours),  positive - you will start home insulation .  Information on how long your isolation will last and certificates can be found on the Internet Patient Account and in the mojeIKP application .    Attention! Antigen tests are carried out in pharmacies. After a negative antigen test result, you can generate an EU COVID Certificate (UCC), but it will only be valid for 48 hours .    If you fall ill with the coronavirus and confirm the disease with the antigen test, you will not get the convalescent status and the EU COVID Certificate after 10 days!    Recover status confirmed by UCC can only be obtained after confirming the disease with  a PCR test performed at the collection point . Check how to sign up for a test at a download point .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220206124352/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/jak-zrobic-test-na-koronawirusa-w-aptece

No change  Limited contact tracing in place.    I was in close contact with a person who tested positive. Should I report it somewhere?  If you are in close contact with a person infected with the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus (this person has obtained a confirmed, positive PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus infection), report this fact to the sanitary inspection. Use the online form: Application for quarantine or isolation by the Sanepid.    If you have questions about quarantine, please call the hotline to contact the sanitary inspection : +48 22 25 00 115. The  hotline is open 24 hours a day.    Important! If you know you have been in close contact with an infected or sick person, stay home - even if you have not yet decided to quarantine, and you are feeling well. Avoid contact with other people. You can infect them if you find out that you are infected. If this is not possible, use all required personal protective equipment.    Attention! If you have been vaccinated for COVID-19, you will not be placed in quarantine. The rule applies from December 28, 2020.    However, from December 15, family  members of people suffering from COVID19 must undergo a coronavirus test, regardless of the certificate they have.    https://archive.fo/wXmsk

Social distance and face masks  Restrictions on movement  1.5 meters - the minimum distance between pedestrians  Obligation to maintain a distance of at least 1.5 meters between pedestrians.    The following are excluded from this obligation:    parents with children requiring care (up to 13 years of age),  people living together or running a farm,  people with a disability certificate, people with a disability degree, people with a certificate of need for special education, people who are unable to move independently and their guardians.  Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  The nose and mouth may only be covered with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / client service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    Important! Only persons with a medical certificate or a document confirming:    pervasive development disorders,  mental disorders,  moderate, severe or severe intellectual disability,  difficulty uncovering or covering your mouth or nose on your own.  advanced neurological, respiratory or circulatory disorders with respiratory or circulatory failure.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220121112908/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

Booster dose  If you are over 50 years of age and 5 months have passed since you vaccinated, you can now have a booster dose of the COVID-19 vaccine. All other adults may receive a booster dose 6 months after the full dose of the vaccine. Vaccinations are the most effective weapon in the fight against severe disease and death.    https://archive.fo/eEqAV

6/2/22    We want as many people as possible to receive the preparation against Covid-19 in the shortest possible time. It is in the interest of all of us - the vaccine offers a real chance of recovery.    E-referral    This is the document that entitles you to have the vaccine. In most cases, it is generated automatically for people who can sign up for a vaccination. Only in some cases do patients report to the doctor for this document. This happens when a given person does not have a PESEL number, or in the case of specific patients with the indicated diseases - they are informed about it.    The e-referral is valid for 90 days, but don't hesitate. If you have the opportunity, sign up for the vaccination now!    Registration for vaccination    Anyone who has an e-referral can sign up for a vaccination. There are several ways to do this:    call the helpline 989,  register online via e-Registration,  send an SMS saying SzczepimySie to the number 880 333 333,  sign up directly at the vaccination point (preferably by phone),  use the drive-thru point .     https://web.archive.org/web/20220127030346/https://www.gov.pl/web/szczepimysie/jak-sie--zaszczepic

Schools had a delayed two week start until September 13th. After this date all employees in state companies and public institutions will have to be vaccinated or have tests done in order to return to work.   Archived link: web/20211011122544/https://www.rferl.org/a/kosovo-schools-delay-covid/31433978.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20211115162149/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/
No evidence of policy change.

Students in public and private university institutions must possess any of the  evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2, in order to be allowed to enter the building of the  institution.    4.1 Certificate of vaccination with at least two doses or one dose of Janssen vaccine  against COVID-19;  4.2 Persons with medical evidence from a specialist in the relevant field that they  have contraindications and are exempt from vaccination, must possess a  negative RT-PCR test for COVID 19 not older than one week;    The teaching process in public and private institutions of higher education, as well as  in vocational and non-formal education institutions, can take place with physical  presence provided that groups over 50 people are accommodated in no more than 50% of  the space.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211160214/https://mfa-ks.net/assets/cms/uploads/files/covid-19/THE%20GOVERNMENT%20DECISION%20ON%20PREVENTING%20AND%20FIGHTING%20COVID-19%20PANDEMICS_compressed.pdf

All employees of public institutions, central and local public enterprises, private  businesses, organizations, as well as other entities, must possess one of the following  evidence, in order to be allowed to enter the work premises:  4.1 Certificate of vaccination with at least two doses or one dose of Janssen vaccine  against COVID-19;  4.2 Persons with medical evidence from a specialist in the relevant field that they  have contraindications and are exempt from vaccination, must possess a  negative RT-PCR test for COVID 19 not older than one week;    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211160214/https://mfa-ks.net/assets/cms/uploads/files/covid-19/THE%20GOVERNMENT%20DECISION%20ON%20PREVENTING%20AND%20FIGHTING%20COVID-19%20PANDEMICS_compressed.pdf

Unless otherwise stated in other sector-specific guidelines, health, non-health institutions and other sectors open to the public must limit the number of persons in the building, so that:  ?	The clients and employees are able to maintain at least 2 meters physical distance with limited capacity.  ?	The maximum number of persons must be 1 person in 8 square meters, always respecting the general measures to prevent the spread of COVID-19.  ?	The maximum number of persons must be 50 persons in closed environments, premises of over 100 square meters, always respecting the general measures to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Unless otherwise specified in this Decision, indoor gatherings of up to thirty (30) persons  (workshops, meetings, seminars, trainings or other gatherings) are allowed. Except those  under the age of 12, participants are obliged to possess any of the evidence mentioned in  points 25.1 to 25.3 in order to be allowed to enter these premises, and the organizer is  obliged to provide a physical distance of one (1) meter between persons and check the  relevant evidence, such as:  25.1 Certificate of vaccination with at least two doses or one dose of Janssen  vaccine against COVID-19;  25.2 Persons with medical evidence issued by the specialist doctor of the  respective field verifying that they have contraindications and are exempt  from vaccination must present the negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19,  which should not be older than 48 hours;  25.3 Single dose vaccination certificate, not older than one (1) month.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211160214/https://mfa-ks.net/assets/cms/uploads/files/covid-19/THE%20GOVERNMENT%20DECISION%20ON%20PREVENTING%20AND%20FIGHTING%20COVID-19%20PANDEMICS_compressed.pdf

Movement Restrictions  Is a curfew in place? Yes.  With limited exceptions, movement of individuals is restricted from 00:00 to 05:00.  Access to all public institutions, malls and dining inside restaurants is not permissible without evidence of vaccination, a negative PRC or rapid negative antigen test. See full details under entry/exit requirements.  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No  Public transport is allowed to operate.  Taxis are allowed to work with up to two passengers.  Wearing a mask is mandatory, in all cases except:  When walking outdoors, alone.  While driving a vehicle alone or in a group with no more than four persons  When running, cycling, and exercising  While eating or drinking    https://web.archive.org/web/20211115162149/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/
No evidence of policy change.

Public transport staff and passengers must possess any of the evidence mentioned in  points 25.1 to 25.3, in order to be allowed to operate, respectively travel on public and  international transport, except persons under the age of 12.     25.1 Certificate of vaccination with at least two doses or one dose of Janssen  vaccine against COVID-19;  25.2 Persons with medical evidence issued by the specialist doctor of the  respective field verifying that they have contraindications and are exempt  from vaccination must present the negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19,  which should not be older than 48 hours;  25.3 Single dose vaccination certificate, not older than one (1) month    Passenger road transport operators are allowed to work using 50% of the seating  capacity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211160214/https://mfa-ks.net/assets/cms/uploads/files/covid-19/THE%20GOVERNMENT%20DECISION%20ON%20PREVENTING%20AND%20FIGHTING%20COVID-19%20PANDEMICS_compressed.pdf

Restriction of citizens' movement shall be from 00:00 to 05:00, except:  13.1 Cases of an emergency nature (to seek medical help, purchase medication,  provide care or medical assistance, avoid injury, or escape the risk of injury);  13.2 Circulation for health, safety personnel, and operators performing public  works and services;  13.3 Night shift personnel of economic operators who ensure the functioning of  the supply chain (including transport of goods/services), but provided that  they are provided with a special permit from the EDI system of the Tax  Administration of Kosovo;  13.4 Persons who provide proof that they must be at the airport during the  circulation restriction, because they have to travel by plane;  13.5 Persons to whom a special temporary permit is issued by the Emergency  Operational Centre of the Ministry of Internal Affairs, according to point 15,  due to the necessity of circulation during curfew.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211160214/https://mfa-ks.net/assets/cms/uploads/files/covid-19/THE%20GOVERNMENT%20DECISION%20ON%20PREVENTING%20AND%20FIGHTING%20COVID-19%20PANDEMICS_compressed.pdf

No change in policy.    1. This decision shall apply to the entire territory of the Republic of Kosovo.    B. [Entries and exits of foreign citizens to and from the Republic of Kosovo]    2. Every person who enters the Republic of Kosovo shall possess one of the following evidence:    2.1 Vaccination certificate for complete vaccination (with two doses) against COVID-19;  2.2 A negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19, not older than 72 hours;  2.3 Evidence that the person has passed COVID-19 (positive RT-PCR test issued not less  than 21 days and not more than 180 days or positive result of serological antibody  test - IgG, issued no more than 30 days ago;  2.4 Rapid negative antigen test not older than 48 hours.    3. Citizens of the Republic of Kosovo, as well as persons with temporary or permanent residence  permits in Kosovo, who enter the Republic of Kosovo and do not possess one of the evidences  according to points 2.1 to 2.4 shall self-isolate for 7 days. These persons shall complete the  statement under oath for self-isolation at the relevant border crossing point.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101173230/https://gzk.rks-gov.net/ActDocumentDetail.aspx?ActID=50069
No evidence of policy change.

Every person who enters the Republic of Kosovo shall possess one of the following  evidence:  2.1 Certificate of full vaccination with two doses or a single-dose of Janssen  (J&J) vaccine not exceeding more than 12 months after receiving the last  dose;  2.2 Certificate of vaccination with a single dose accompanied with a negative  RT-PCR test for COVID-19, not older than 48 hours;  2.3 Evidence that the person has recovered from COVID-19 in the last 90  days (positive RT-PCR test issued in the last 21â90 days);  2.4 Evidence that the person has received the third / booster dose;  2.5 Evidence of negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19, not older than 48 hours.    Citizens of the Republic of Kosovo who do not have two doses of vaccine are  obliged to respect home quarantine for a period of seven (7) days from the  entry into the territory of the Republic of Kosovo;     https://web.archive.org/web/20220211160214/https://mfa-ks.net/assets/cms/uploads/files/covid-19/THE%20GOVERNMENT%20DECISION%20ON%20PREVENTING%20AND%20FIGHTING%20COVID-19%20PANDEMICS_compressed.pdf

esting available across Kosovo    COVID-19 Testing  Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Kosovo? Yes  There are PCR and rapid antigen tests available from several private labs in Pristina and major towns in Kosovo.  The main public hospital in Pristina, the University Clinical Center of Kosovo (UCCK), provides free travel testing without a referral although availability and scheduling depend on demand.  Are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Turn-around time for results from the private clinics vary from several hours to 24 hours and are available via email and hard copy. Results from UCCK are reportedly available within 24 hours, but it is best to check with them due to expected higher demand.  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions, please review the following page: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/covid-testing-required-us-entry.html   If you are in Kosovo and have COVID-19 related questions, are symptomatic, or need information regarding testing, please call toll free 038 200 80 800, or dial 194.  The U.S. Embassy does not endorse or recommend any particular healthcare provider, but below is a list of clinics and hospitals who are providing tests. Please contact them directly for details on location, tests offered, and pricing:  Medical and Laboratory Services SHPK, +383 48 111 000 or +383 38 600 188  Prolab, +383 49 789 410  Olive Lab, +383 38 720 055, +383 49 520 056  UBT â Laboratori I Mikrobiologis e Klinike, + 383 46 500 777, +383 46 500 888  Avicena, +383 49 825 555  UCCK â University Clinical Center Kosovo (public hospital), +381 38 500 600    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101164843/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/

Has the government of Kosovo approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use? Yes  The Kosovo Ministry of Health has approved the use of rapid antigen testing. The standard test in Kosovo for diagnostic purposes is COVID-19 (SARS-CoV-2) molecular detection of viral RNA using real-time RT-PCR. Serology testing has been used for surveillance as well as diagnostic purposes.  Are vaccines available in Kosovo for U.S. citizens to receive? Yes. The vaccine is available to both resident U.S. citizens and visitors without an appointment. For more details please see Kosovo Ministry of Health information available in Albanian and Serbian only.  Which vaccines are available in Kosovo? Astra Zeneca and Pfizer. The vaccine is limited to individuals over the age of 12.  The United States Government does not plan to provide COVID-19 vaccinations to private U.S. citizens overseas. Please follow host country developments and guidelines regarding COVID-19 vaccination. A European Union Digital COVID Certificate or Romanian-issued âDigital Green Certificate/Green Passâ is necessary to access many public locations and to participate in certain activities such as: indoor or outdoor seated dining at restaurants, access to shopping malls, museums, exhibitions, cultural sites, non-essential stores, swimming pools, gyms and other venues. The Green Pass is not required for locations that provide essential services, such as food stores, pharmacies with direct access, or religious services.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220214183531/https://ro.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  It is a legal requirement to wear a medical-grade mask in all indoor and outdoor public spaces.   http://web.archive.org/web/20220214183735/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/romania/coronavirus

Passengers traveling from Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa and Zimbabwe are not permitted to enter Romania - effective until February 6, 2022. All passengers arriving in Romania are required to complete a digital Passenger Locator Form at least 24 hours before arriving in the country. Foreign citizens may enter Romania without a negative COVID-19 test, but are subject to quarantine requirements if a negative RT-PCR COVID-19 test is not presented, regardless of vaccination status. Beginning January 9, 2022, foreign citizens arriving in Romania from third countries (countries that are not member of the European Union, the European Economic Area or the Swiss Confederation) must quarantine for 5 days if they are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 within 180 days of travel, or 10 days if they are unvaccinated or have not recently recovered from COVID-19.  https://archive.fo/su6HG

All passengers who are travelling to Romania must complete a Passenger Locator Form (PLF). The document should be completed no more than 72 hours before entering the country. It can also be completed at the point of entry into the country. As of 1 February Romania is no longer using a traffic light system to classify countries for travel. All travellers (Romanians or foreign citizens) entering Romania must follow the same entry requirements.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220214185700/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/romania/entry-requirements  As of January 9, 2022, foreign citizens arriving in Romania must quarantine for 5 days if they cannot present proof of vaccination, recovery from COVID-19 within 180 days of travel, or a negative PCR COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours prior to boarding.  http://web.archive.org/web/20220214183531/https://ro.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Businesses in the capital must switch to remote work for:  - at least 30 percent of the total number of employees;  - all employees over 60 years of age and suffering from chronic diseases. People above 60 in Moscow must stay at home or in their country house. They can go out only in these cases: when they need to go to the store, walk their pets, take out the trash, go to work, to the clinic or hospital, take a walk or play sports in the fresh air. They may also leave the house if there is a direct threat to life and health. These measures do not apply to those who have had COVID-19, as well as those who have been vaccinated against coronavirus.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220119000615/https://www.mos.ru/city/projects/measures/

Starting from 10 December 2021, entry into Russia is not allowed for any passengers arriving from, or having visited during the last fourteen days, Botswana, Eswatini, Hong Kong, Lesotho, Madagascar, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Tanzania and Zimbabwe. Any citizen of the Russian Federation over the age of 18 can register for the vaccination. The following categories of citizens are subject to priority vaccination: persons over 60 years of age; social workers and others who work with large numbers of people; people with chronic diseases. The Russian government has approved three domestically developed and produced vaccines for use in the country including Sputnik V, EpiVacCorona, and CoviVac.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220122153505/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Mass events can now go ahead under strict restrictions. Events have been categorised into low, medium and high risk:  - Low risk: capacity of 100 or 50% of venue maximum capacity. Defined as events where participants are wearing masks, food and drinks are prohibited, sitting is mandatory, and event takes place without singing, encouragement or other loud vocal expressions.  - Medium risk: capacity of 100 or 25% of venue maximum capacity. Defined as events where participants are wearing masks and here is a fixed sitting or standing arrangement.   - High risk: capacity of 20 people. Defined as events in a public catering operation or a non-low-risk mass event and a medium-risk mass event; this includes weddings, parties and other celebrations.   All mass event attendees must be fully vaccinated or have proof of full COVID-19 recovery within the past 90 days. Funerals are exempt from these restrictions, as are meetings of public authorities, elections, and mass events necessary for the course of the following professional competitions in selected sports.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220123200410/https://korona.gov.sk/obmedzenia-pre-hromadne-podujatia/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220123195717/https://www.uvzsr.sk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4988%3Ainformacia-k-novym-vyhlakam-uvz-sr-respiratory-hromadne-podujatia-prevadzky-otp-na-pracoviskach&catid=56%3Atlaove-spravy&Itemid=62

Everyone aged over 12 years and 2 months arriving from all countries by all means of transport must register in advance of travel by completing the âEhranicaâ form on the Slovak governmentâs website. For those who are not EU citizens and are entering the country unvaccinated, an isolation period of at least 10 days is required. Persons who have visited South Africa, Botswana, Namibia, Lesotho, Eswatini, Mozambique, Zimbabwe, in the last 14 days prior to entering Slovakia must undergo isolation for at least 14 days, regardless of vaccination status.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220123203431/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovakia/entry-requirements

Everyone aged over 12 years and 2 months arriving from all countries by all means of transport must register in advance of travel by completing the âeHranicaâ form on the Slovak governmentâs website.  Fully vaccinated and recently recovered travellers do not need to quarantine but must carry proof of vaccination or recovery. Unvaccinated travellers must either self-quarantine for 5 days and then quarantine ends as long as they remain asymptomatic; OR travellers may take a PCR test at any time after entry and self-isolation will end upon receipt of the negative results.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220205133911/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220205134008/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovakia/entry-requirements

Registration for COVID-19 vaccination is open to anyone from the age of 12. Certain hospitals are offering vaccinations without registration. The national vaccination programme is currently using the Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna, and Janssen (Johnson and Johnson) vaccines. The Recovered - Vaccinated - Tested rule mandatory for all employees  The Government ordinance stipulates that the Recovered - Vaccinated â Tested rule (RVT rule*) must be met by all employees as well as all users of services or activities, except in cases of the emergency supply of basic necessities of life, the provision of public order, security and defence, emergency medical assistance and protection and rescue, urgent healthcare services, urgent procedures involving social and family issues, urgent personal assistance, and protection and rescue.  Employees  The RVT rule must be met for the duration of work by all employees and persons who work for an employer on another legal basis, or are self-employed. The requirements of the RVT rule do not have to be met while a person is working from home.  https://archive.vn/ZCO4V#selection-1117.0-1173.71

https://archive.vn/ZCO4V#selection-1643.0-1647.108  The organisation of public cultural events in open public spaces is not permitted, but it is permitted in enclosed public spaces with fixed seating, whereby every other seat must be left vacant, the use of face masks is mandatory, and all participants must comply with the recovered/vaccinated/tested rule.    Public cultural events may only be held on condition that the performers and people involved in the organisation of the event that have direct contact with visitors meet the requirements of the recovered/vaccinated/tested rule. This condition does not apply to persons under the age of 12. The public cultural event can be attended by a maximum of 750 visitors.

Gatherings (socialising) are temporarily prohibited, and are only permitted for groups of persons who are immediate family members or share the same household.  https://archive.vn/ZCO4V#selection-1643.0-1647.108  The operation of establishments providing music for dancing or entertainment programmes (discotheques, night clubs) are not permitted.

Public transport is running as usual. However, as of 10 January 2022, passenger numbers will be limited.  Passengers must provide the transport operator with proof of compliance with the recovered/vaccinated/tested rule. The use of masks is mandatory for drivers and passengers.  https://archive.vn/ZCO4V#selection-1643.0-1647.108
NA

https://archive.vn/R4Ej3  https://archive.vn/AjDFa  Entry into the Republic of Slovenia without quarantine is permitted to travellers who have recovered from Covid-19 or are fully vaccinated or have been tested (the RVT rule). A person shall comply with the RVT rule by presenting one of the proofs/certificates defined in ordinance on the method of meeting the condition of recovery, vaccination and testing to curb the spread of SARS-CoV-2 virus infections.

Financing of testing  The funds for testing with HAG tests and the HAG tests for self-testing are provided from the budget of the Republic of Slovenia.  https://archive.vn/ZCO4V#selection-1725.0-1753.47  The right to free testing with HAG tests at health-care providers is granted only to persons  with permanent or temporary residence in Slovenia,  who are employed at an employer with a head office in Slovenia, or  who are diplomatic representatives in Slovenia.
NA

https://archive.vn/ZCO4V#selection-1725.0-1753.47  Wear a face mask  Surgical mask or a FFP2 mask are mandatory: in all closed public spaces,on public transport,in open public spaces or outside, if a distance of at least 1,5 metres is not maintained and  in personal vehicles.
Education continues to operate in person, but distance learning is recommended wherever possible (esp. at university level): https://archive.ph/guIOp

Primary school, high school and special high school  The overriding principle is still in-person education.  Measures should be taken, such as being outdoors as much as possible, avoiding congregating in large groups indoors, and where possible avoiding mixing different classes.    Adult education and higher education institutions  Partially remote learning is recommended for higher education institutions, to create distance inside the lecture rooms, but will not apply as a fulltime measure.    Practical classes, such as examinations, and other adult education should be continued with risk-reducing measures in place.    https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations

9th Feb 2022, Sweden scrapped almost all of its few pandemic restrictions on Wednesday and stopped most testing for COVID-19, even as the pressure on the healthcare systems remained high and some scientists begged for more patience in fighting the disease.    Advice and recommendations  - Get vaccinated if you can  The Swedish Public Health Agency recommends that everyone aged 12 and older be vaccinated against covid-19. It reduces the risk of serious illness and death.    - Stay home if you have symptoms  Anyone with symptoms of Covid-19 should stay at home and  avoid close contacts with others if you are ill with symptoms of Covid-19.    - Special advice to those not vaccinated  Not being vaccinated increases the risk of serious illness from Covid-19. To avoid becoming infected, people who are unvaccinated should be extra careful and avoid crowded indoor environments.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220209115741/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations    https://web.archive.org/web/20220210135400/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/sweden-declare-pandemic-over-despite-warnings-scientists-2022-02-09/
Recommendation to work from home wherever possible; has not changed since last data entry: https://archive.ph/guIOp

It reduces the risk of serious illness and death.    - Stay home if you have symptoms  Anyone with symptoms of Covid-19 should stay at home and  avoid close contacts with others if you are ill with symptoms of Covid-19.    - Special advice to those not vaccinated  Not being vaccinated increases the risk of serious illness from Covid-19. To avoid becoming infected, people who are unvaccinated should be extra careful and avoid crowded indoor environments.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220209115741/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations    https://web.archive.org/web/20220210135400/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/sweden-declare-pandemic-over-despite-warnings-scientists-2022-02-09/
Public events (indoor) with more than 50 people cannot take place without a covid certification: https://archive.ph/guIOp

Public gatherings and public events  For indoor events with more than 20 and a maximum of 50 participants, all participants must be seated, groups must be limited to a maximum of 8 people, and a distance of one metre must be kept between parties. Vaccination certificates can be used.  For indoor events with more than 50 participants, vaccination certificates must be used, together with assigned seats, and a distance of one meter must be kept between parties.  For public gatherings and events, as well as exhibitions/fairs indoors, with vaccination pass requirements, the maximum number of participants will be 500. If the premises are sectioned, and participants from different sections do not get in contact with those from other sections, each section can have maximum 500 participants.  Special instructions apply to religious events and are outlined in the current regulations.    Fairs  Maximum 500 visitors for trade fairs. An organizer can divide the gathering or event into sections. Then the maximum ceiling applies to each individual section.    Organisers must determine the maximum number of visitors and exhibitors based on the requirement of 10 square metres per person.    Private gatherings in rented premises   Private gatherings held in rented premises can have a maximum of 20 participants. This does not apply to funeral ceremonies. Funeral ceremonies and moments of remembrance will be exempt and can thus have 50 participants.    Venues serving food and drink  The size of parties is limited to eight people.  Guests must be seated, with at least one meter between the groups.  Venues must close no later than 11 pm, which means that the venue has to be empty at 11 pm.   Indoor trading establishments and markets  Trading establishments must determine the maximum number of visitors based on the requirement of 10 square metres per person.  Places with cultural and leisure activities   At least 10 square metres per person is required.  There are exceptions for businesses that are focused on children and young people, for example sports practice and competitions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220125155512/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations

According to the Ministry, the COVID-19 measures will be lifted in two stages. The restrictions of the first stage will be lifted on February 9, whereas the second stage is due to begin on April 1.    In the first stage, Sweden will lift the requirement to present a vaccination certificate when entering different venues, including public events, bars, restaurants, shopping centres, and public transport.    This means that travellers and citizens of the country will be permitted restriction-free entry to the majority of places starting from February 9.    Other restrictions will also be lifted next week. Public gathering, eating and drinking establishments, and shopping centres will no longer have a limit of persons allowed in one area at the same time.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220205070451/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/sweden-to-lift-majority-of-covid-19-restriction-on-february-9/

19th Jan 2022, Sweden Removes Pre-Entry Testing Requirement    Travellers are no longer considered to represent a particular risk that would affect the spread of the Omicron variant in Sweden. For this reason, the specific requirement for a negative COVID-19 result from a test conducted within 48 hours of arrival to Sweden is no longer considered to be a proportional measure.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220121190528/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/sweden-removes-pre-entry-testing-requirement/

A ban on entry to Sweden is in effect for non-essential travel from most countries outside the EU/EEA. The ban does not apply to Swedish citizens, citizens of another EU/EEA country or citizens from a number of exempt countries. Swedish citizens and foreign nationals who are registered in Sweden are always entitled to travel into Sweden.    Read more under International travel, where you will find information about which countries are exempt from the entry ban and what is needed in order to be granted an exemption from the entry ban.     Foreign nationals aged 18 or more travelling to Sweden from countries within the EU/EEA or the Nordic countries must present the EU Covid certificate or proof of vaccination against Covid-19 from certain other countries. Foreign nationals travelling to Sweden from other countries must be exempted from the travel ban and show evidence of a negative test of Covid-19, from within the past 72 hours. More information in Swedish at Regeringen.se.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220125155512/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations

9th Feb 2022, there is a ban on non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU/EEA. This ban applies to foreign nationals and remains in effect until 31 March 2022. There are a number of exemptions to the ban based on work or studies, family connections or urgent family reasons, as well as a number of countries whose residents are exempted.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220131153810/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

To avoid becoming infected, people who are unvaccinated should be extra careful and avoid crowded indoor environments.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220209115741/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations    https://web.archive.org/web/20220210135400/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/sweden-declare-pandemic-over-despite-warnings-scientists-2022-02-09/

7/2/22  All travellers are to isolate for 3 days whilst awaiting arrival PCR test    Entry rules in response to coronavirus (COVID-19)  Travellers arriving in Tajikistan must provide confirmation of a negative PCR test, issued within 72 hours of arrival. The test must be a COVID-19 PCR swab test. Other test results including antibody tests are not accepted.    COVID-19 entry requirements may change at short notice, and travellers to Tajikistan are strongly encouraged to check the specifics with their airline, including the timeframes for undertaking COVID-19 PCR tests, before travel.    Entry to Tajikistan  Land border crossings between Tajikistan and Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan, China and Afghanistan are closed to travellers. A small number of border points with Uzbekistan are open to Tajik citizens only. Some border points with Uzbekistan, China and Kyrgyzstan are open for cargo only. Flights are operating from several destinations. See International Travel section for further details.    Testing / screening on arrival  Travellers arriving in Tajikistan will be screened and be required to have a PCR test on arrival.    Quarantine requirements  Travellers entering Tajikistan are not currently subject to quarantine but are required to self-isolate for at least three days upon arrival; this may be subject to change.    Testing on departure  A âfit-to-flyâ negative PCR result is required to enable travellers to board flights at Dushanbe Airport. Additionally, most destinations and transits require travellers to have a negative PCR test before departing Tajikistan. Travellers should check the regulations at their destination and any transit points and obtain the required tests before travel. Travellers may be screened by having their temperature taken and assessed for other COVID-19 symptoms on departure from Tajikistan.        https://web.archive.org/web/20220103124453/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/tajikistan/entry-requirements

Most services are available in Turkey without restrictions. Quote: "Uzbekistan announces tightened international entry restrictions in an ongoing effort to stem the spread of COVID-19. Effective Jan. 15, all international arrivals will be required to present proof of a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken no more than 48 hours before arrival."  "Authorities currently maintain a number of other international entry restrictions. All incoming, outgoing, and transit flights with South Africa, Botswana, Namibia, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Madagascar, Lesotho, Tanzania, Eswatini, and Hong Kong are suspended. Nonresident foreign nationals who have been in one of these countries within the previous 14 days will not be permitted to enter Uzbekistan.  All travelers currently entering Uzbekistan via air, rail, or vehicle border crossing must present proof of a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before arrival in a testing laboratory approved by authorities.  Persons entering Uzbekistan without a valid test will be required to undergo a rapid antigen test at specialized facilities operating in airports, train stations, and border crossing points at their own expense. Uzbek nationals who test positive will be quarantined in a government facility, while foreign nationals who test positive will be barred from entry. Travelers from certain countries including Australia, Austria, Belgium, the Czech Republic, Germany, Denmark, Israel, Italy, the Netherlands, Egypt, and the UK may be required to self-isolate at their residence or at a hotel at their own expense for 10 days on arrival."    Archive ink  https://archive.vn/7Y1SD#selection-1843.0-1843.49
